screen.question: How long does an elephant pregnancy last?
screen.explanation: Elephants give birth to a single baby after a 22-month-long pregnancy. That’s the longest gestation period of any mammal.
screen.source: http://worldwildlife.org/species/elephant (next to last paragraph in overview)

screen.question: Elephants have good long-term memories.
screen.explanation: Elephants do possess incredible memories. Their extraordinary recollection helps them find places to drink and eat food. Elephants also develop remarkable social memories that allow them to remember dozens, even hundreds, of other elephants.

screen.question: What is one way forest elephants differ from savanna elephants?
screen.explanation: Forest elephants are smaller and darker than savanna elephants and their tusks are straighter and point downward, allowing them to move through the dense undergrowth of their habitat in the forests of central Africa. You can save elephants by supporting ecotourism—travel with WWF to Africa to see these magnificent animals in the wild!
screen.attribution: WWF-US Deborah Gainer WWF Cannon Carlos Drews

screen.question: An elephant’s _____ is an elongated fusion of its nose and upper lip and contains approximately 150,000 muscles.
screen.explanation: An elephant trunk has up to 150,000 muscles. The human body has about 600 muscles. Among its many uses, an elephant’s trunk picks up objects, trumpets warnings, and greets other elephants.

screen.question: What are female elephants called?
screen.explanation: Female elephants are called cows. Led by a matriarch, elephants are organized into complex social structures of cows, juveniles, and calves. Male elephants, known as bulls. tend to live in isolation.
screen.source: http://worldwildlife.org/species/elephant (next to last paragraph in overview)

screen.question: Elephants’ _____ skin helps keep them cool.
screen.explanation: An elephant’s wrinkly skin keeps him cool. Moisture is trapped within the wrinkles and then evaporates more slowly than if the skin surface was flat. The elephant also radiates excess heat by fanning its large ears.

screen.question: What is the main food in an elephant’s diet?
screen.explanation: Most of the elephant’s diet consists of grasses but elephants are also known to eat bark, leaves, fruit, and agricultural crops.
screen.source: http://www.arkive.org/african-elephant/loxodonta-africana/ (African Elephant description, last paragraph) http://www.arkive.org/asian-elephant/elephas-maximus/ (Asian Elephant description, last paragraph)

screen.question: Elephant-human conflict exists because:

choices.choice: Elephants are taking up more space
Elephants have lost habitats and migratory routes to human settlements

screen.explanation: As wild spaces vanish, elephants are forced into closer contact with people. WWF works to ease reduce conflict between humans and elephants.

screen.question: The most immediate threat to elephants is poachers who kill them for their:
screen.explanation: The illegal demand for ivory is the biggest driver of elephant poaching. Despite a global ban on international ivory sales, tens of thousands of elephants are killed annually to meet a growing demand for ivory products. You can save elephants by making sure you never buy ivory.

screen.question: What is WWF doing to help elephants?

choices.choice: Fighting poaching and stopping demand for illegal ivory
Reducing conflict between people and elephants
Working with governments and partners to maintain large conservation areas

screen.explanation: WWF equips and trains law enforcement teams so they can conduct regular and effective antipoaching patrols. We work to establish new protected areas to provide safe havens for elephants. WWF also trains wildlife managers and local communities to use modern methods and tools to mitigate human-elephant conflict.
